entry.title: On the Expressivity of Markov Reward | DeepMind Blog
entry.summary: Our main results prove that while reward can express many tasks, there exist instances of each task type that no Markov reward function can capture. We then provide a set of polynomial-time algorithms...
entry.content: Our main results prove that while reward can express many tasks, there exist instances of each task type that no Markov reward function can capture. We then provide a set of polynomial-time algorithms that construct a reward function which allows an agent to optimize tasks of each of these three types, and correctly determine when no such reward function exists.

entry.title: How to Package and Distribute Machine Learning Models with MLFlow | KDnuggets
entry.summary: MLFlow is a tool to manage the end-to-end lifecycle of a Machine Learning model. Likewise, the installation and configuration of an MLFlow service is addressed and examples are added on how to generat...
entry.content: MLFlow is a tool to manage the end-to-end lifecycle of a Machine Learning model. Likewise, the installation and configuration of an MLFlow service is addressed and examples are added on how to generate and share projects with MLFlow.

UVQ: Measuring YouTube's Perceptual Video Quality | Google AI Blog
entry.summary: Posted by Yilin Wang, Staff Software Engineer, YouTube and Feng Yang, Senior Staff Software Engineer, Google Research Online video sharing platforms, like YouTube, need to understand perceptual video ...
entry.content: Posted by Yilin Wang, Staff Software Engineer, YouTube and Feng Yang, Senior Staff Software Engineer, Google Research Online video sharing platforms, like YouTube, need to understand perceptual video quality (i.e., a user's subjective perception of video quality) in order to better optimize and improve user experience. Video quality assessment (VQA) attempts to build a bridge between video signals and perceptual quality by using objective mathematical models to approximate the subjective opinion...

entry.title: Support Vector Machines: An Intuitive Approach | KDnuggets
entry.summary: This post focuses on building an intuition of the Support Vector Machine algorithm in a classification context and an in-depth understanding of how that graphical intuition can be mathematically repre...
entry.content: This post focuses on building an intuition of the Support Vector Machine algorithm in a classification context and an in-depth understanding of how that graphical intuition can be mathematically represented in the form of a loss function. We will also discuss kernel tricks and a more useful variant of SVM with a soft margin.

entry.title: Discovering when an agent is present in a system | DeepMind Blog
entry.summary: We want to build safe, aligned artificial general intelligence (AGI) systems that pursue the intended goals of its designers. Causal influence diagrams (CIDs) are a way to model decision-making situat...
entry.content: We want to build safe, aligned artificial general intelligence (AGI) systems that pursue the intended goals of its designers. Causal influence diagrams (CIDs) are a way to model decision-making situations that allow us to reason about agent incentives. By relating training setups to the incentives that shape agent behaviour, CIDs help illuminate potential risks before training an agent and can inspire better agent designs. But how do we know when a CID is an accurate model of a training setup?

entry.content: Posted by Brian Ichter and Karol Hausman, Research Scientists, Google Research, Brain Team Over the last several years, we have seen significant progress in applying machine learning to robotics. However, robotic systems today are capable of executing only very short, hard-coded commands, such as ‚ÄúPick up an apple,‚Äù because they tend to perform best with clear tasks and rewards. They struggle with learning to perform long-horizon tasks and reasoning about abstract goals, such as a user prompt li...
